title: The New York PR maven entangled in Leon Black's legal battle
text:
One memorial to start: Due Diligence would like to express its sincere condolences to the family of Lord Paul Myners, a giant of the City and a dedicated public servant. He was a great supporter of this newsletter and frequently offered up his wise counsel on a diverse range of issues. Paul also had a wicked sense of humour and will be sorely missed by many members of the DD team.

Happening today: It's not too late to sign up for our first Due Diligence: Dialogues event featuring Goldman Sachs veteran Gregg Lemkau. Register for free here and join us virtually at 9:30am EST, 14:30 GMT.

Rubenstein receives an unwanted request from Leon Black

“The greatest material curse to the profession, despite all its advantages, is undoubtedly the telephone.”

Those are the words of Allen Dulles, the American statesman who began his career spying on Nazis in Switzerland, and told his minions to unplug the wretched receiver during sensitive conversations — or better still, keep it in a box or cupboard.

Such advice might resonate with New York PR man Steven Rubenstein, whose eponymous firm has worked “with everyone from Presidents to Popes”, according to its website.

That's because Rubenstein and his phone have been dragged into a bitter legal dispute involving Leon Black, the billionaire investor who was until recently chief executive of Apollo Global Management.

Black is being sued by a Russian fashion model, Guzel Ganieva, who says he sexually abused her during their relationship and then damaged her reputation by publicly accusing her of extortion after she posted her grievances on Twitter.

The billionaire denies the allegations, and his lawyers have called the entire lawsuit “a work of fiction”.

What's more, they have filed a lawsuit against Ganieva and her lawyers at Wigdor, alleging that they are perpetrators of a wide-ranging extortion scheme “to try to get even more from Mr Black — or destroy him in the process”. Wigdor has rejected the allegations and complained of what they view as an abuse of the legal process.

DD's Mark Vandevelde and Sujeet Indap have more on this extraordinary legal battle here.

Rubenstein is not mentioned in the lawsuit and said he discovered that he was being drawn into the fight in December, when Verizon told him they had received a subpoena from Black's lawyers demanding details of every call and text message sent to or from his iPhone over a 12-month period.

“Any private citizen should be aghast that [a bystander to a lawsuit] could be made the subject of a subpoena calling for all their telephone records simply at the whim of a litigant,” Rubenstein's lawyers wrote in a motion to quash the order.

A representative for Rubenstein told the FT: “We have had absolutely no relationship, or contact of any kind, formal or informal, direct or indirect, with the plaintiff in the underlying matter.”

Unilever/GSK: Fourth time's the charm?

After three failed attempts to buy UK drugmaker GlaxoSmithKline's consumer healthcare business, Unilever refuses to back down.

The British multinational still hopes to pursue a deal with GSK, sources told the FT, despite the pharmaceutical group's dismissal of its latest £50bn offer as one that “fundamentally undervalued” the business it intended to spin off later this year.

Unilever insists that GSK's portfolio of toothpaste, vitamins and other products is a “strong strategic fit” as it shifts its focus away from sluggish areas like food (its portfolio includes Hellmann's mayonnaise and Ben & Jerry's ice cream) and further into the health and beauty sectors.

But many Unilever investors think it should move on. The company's share price tumbled to its lowest level in nearly five years on Monday.

In addition to concerns over the heavy debts Unilever would have to take on to make the deal happen, the FT's Helen Thomas explains investors are fretting over management's decision-making capabilities in general.

Unilever has “lost the plot” by attempting to flaunt its sustainability credentials at the expense of running the business, star fund manager Terry Smith, whose Fundsmith is one of the company's largest shareholders, said last week before the GSK bid was announced.

GSK shareholders have their own reasons to oppose a Unilever takeover, unimpressed by the company's management and emboldened by the bid that the business has the potential to attract other suitors.

“The idea of letting the goons at Unilever run it is laughable,” said Richard Buxton at Jupiter Capital Management, a top-30 shareholder in GSK.

The publicity has worked well for GSK, as the possibility of a bidding war boosted its shares on Monday.

Centrica/NSO: the thin veneer between private equity funds and their investors 

A basic premise of a private equity fund is that institutions committing money to the pool do so without knowing what it is going to be spent on later.

So Centrica, the parent company of Britain's biggest energy company British Gas, couldn't have known when it committed millions of euros of its employees' pension fund cash to private equity group Novalpina Capital that it would be used to buy the Israeli cyberweapon developer NSO Group. The company was blacklisted by the US Department of Commerce last year.

Still, Amnesty International has criticised institutions that invested in Novalpina alongside Centrica for being “directly linked” to human rights abuse.

Centrica has so far avoided such opprobrium, because unlike relatively transparent public pension funds such as the Oregon Public Employees Retirement System and the South Yorkshire Pensions Authority, it kept its involvement in the fraught situation out of the public eye — until DD's Kaye Wiggins and the FT's Mehul Srivastava revealed it with this scoop.

The family office of Belgian billionaire Albert Frère, who died in 2018, was another previously-unknown investor in the fund. Compagnie Nationale à Portefeuille committed about €50m to it.

Both may now come in for far closer scrutiny. Gauthier Parisis, chief legal officer of CNP, said it doesn't take part in the fund's investment decisions. So far, Centrica has stayed silent on the matter.

The situation is messy and moving fast. Novalpina fell apart itself last year, its founding partners stripped of control of the fund in a highly unusual move.

It's a reminder that pension funds and public bodies who blindly hand their cash to buyout groups are ultimately held accountable for what is done with their money — and of how the screen between them and the private equity dealmakers they entrust is paper-thin.

Job moves

  • António Horta-Osório has resigned as chair of Credit Suisse after repeated breaches of coronavirus quarantine rules, including attending the Wimbledon finals and the use of the bank's private jet for a personal holiday to the Maldives.

    His departure comes nine months after he arrived in April, promising a clean-up of the scandal-hit bank. Axel Lehmann, the former chief operating officer and head of the Swiss business at UBS who joined Credit Suisse's board in October, has been drafted in as the bank's new chair.

  • Bridgewater Associates has appointed two co-chief executives to replace David McCormick, who is expected to run for the US Senate. Nir Bar Dea, previously the hedge fund's deputy chief, will share the top job with Mark Bertolini, co-chair of Bridgewater's operating board of directors and a former healthcare executive.

  • Sports streaming service DAZN has named its co-chief executive Shay Segev as its sole chief executive and former Prime Video finance director Darren Waterman as its new finance chief. James Rushton, who had been serving as co-CEO, will step down from the role while remaining at the company.

  • Linklaters has promoted Greg Baker to the newly created role of global head of practice innovation, based in London.
